titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Zelma Corning Brandt (1891-1990) attended Bryn Mawr College from 1909 to 1911. She married Carl Brandt, of the Brandt & Brandt publishing firm, where she worked until 1927. After her divorce, she worked as a correspondent for the Trans-Radio News Agency. She also worked as an observer for the United Nations International League for Human Rights. She was keenly interested in women's rights and was an original member of the Women's International Democratic Federation. She was active in many social, environmental, and political causes.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the papers of Zelma Corning Brandt. Documentation includes: incoming and outgoing correspondence (1907-1988); photographs, notebooks, and publications related to Brandt's travels in India, Africa, China, and Japan; and printed matter from a variety of organizations, such as the National Organization for Women, the Gray Panthers, and anti-Vietnam war groups. The correspondence reflects Brandt's interest in and activities on behalf of a wide range of causes. Although some of the mailings from organizations are routine requests for donations, Brandt's responses are quite vibrant and engaging. Personal correspondence in the collection also reflects her commitment to social and political causes. The collection also includes photographs and some of Brandt's early diaries (1906-1910).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: A paper finding aid is available in the repository.
